pattern_info: Self-drafted / Various free patterns

content: This collection started with just the pumpkin, but I couldn't stop! The eyeball coasters are great for using up scrap yarn.

title: Dino Hoodie

pattern_info: Pattern by Nadiyjournal on Etsy

title: Purple Balloon Dog
description: A playful purple 'balloon' dog that will never pop. Soft, squishy, and fun.
pattern_info: Pattern free on Ravelry by Gloria B http://ravelry.com/patterns/library/balloon-dog-9

content: Such a whimsical piece. It looks just like the real thing but much cuddlier and durable.

title: Cactus Sunset Tapestry
description: Desert vibes in fiber form. A colorful tapestry crochet piece featuring saguaros and sunset hues.
pattern_info: Pattern free on Ravelry by Divine Debris https://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/cool-cactus-wall-hanging
tips: Carry the unused yarn colors inside the stitches for a cleaner back.
Use bobbins for each color to prevent tangling.
Count your stitches carefully—tapestry crochet mistakes are hard to fix!
challenges: Managing multiple yarn colors at once was tricky at first.
Keeping the tension even across color changes took practice.
The cactus shapes required careful attention to the chart.
helpful_tips: Start with a smaller swatch to practice the color changes before committing to the full piece.
A yarn bowl or yarn guide helps keep multiple strands organized.
Blocking really makes the design pop—don't skip it!
narrative: I was inspired to make a tapestry while traveling. The use of simple sc made it approachable, but the color changes kept it interesting!
The technique of carrying unused yarn inside the stitches creates a clean back, but it does make the piece thicker and stiffer than regular crochet.
The most challenging part was the cactus shapes. I had to follow a detailed chart and count stitches carefully to get the proportions right. There were definitely a few rows I had to frog and redo!
Now it hangs in my living room. The colors are so cozy and inviting.

title: Honeycomb Market Tote

pattern_info: Inspired by free pattern on Ravelry by Lindsey Dale https://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/hexagon-tote-bag
tips: Join the hexagons as you go to save time on sewing later.
